Work
on a new building for the Faculty of English in West Road began
in July 2002 and was essentially complete in August of 2004. The
new building is on the site of the former Victorian villa and its
garden, and retains the same address, 9 West Road. The London-based
architectural partnership of Allies and Morrison designed the building
and worked closely with Wates Construction and a team of consultants
The Faculty's administrative staff began moving into it in late August and
early September and the teaching staff began moving into their offices in September.
We made the target date for the move, and were open in time for the start of
The building was funded by grants or donations from the alumni, the University,
the Higher Education Funding Council for England, charitable trusts, private
individuals and corporations. The Faculty's Building Committee worked
closely with the design team to ensure that the completed building is appropriate
The
building provides accommodation for the Faculty of English, the
Department of Anglo-Saxon, Norse, and Celtic, and for the Research
Centre for English and Applied Linguistics. It houses the faculty's
administrative offices, the Faculty Library, a drama studio and
provides IT and audio-visual facilities for teaching, research and
student use. There are meeting rooms, a courtyard garden and social
space in the form of both common rooms and an open area on the ground
floor that looks out onto the courtyard. The Faculty now has a building
that is appropriate for its size and suitable for the Faculty's
range of teaching, research and outreach activities.
The building was opened officially in June 2005 by Her Majesty

column2: and in the same month was given a special award in the

column1: Royal Fine Arts Commission's 'Building of the Year' competition.

column2: 2006 Faculty of English, University of Cambridge
